resources.string:
• Call 911 if safe to do so.

  • Run if you can get out, escape the area.

  • Hide secure in place, lock/barricade doors, turn off lights, silence phones, and be quiet.

  • Fight as a last resort, attack aggressively.

If you are inside:
  • Drop-Cover-Hold under a table or desk or against an inside wall until the shaking stops.

  • Avoid windows, filing cabinets, bookcases and other heavy objects.

  • After the shaking stops, check for injuries and assess your surroundings for damage.

  • Evacuate the building if you feel unsafe or if told to do so by building staff or emergency responders.

  • Do not leave the area/campus without reporting your status to someone in charge.

If you are outside:
  • Move away from trees, signs, buildings, electrical poles and wires.

  • Protect your head with your arms.

  • Proceed to the nearest assembly area.

Persons Who Are Disruptive

If a person displays conduct that is reckless, disorderly, threatening, including self-harmful behavior, and you are concerned for your safety or the safety of others, please call 911 or the UCI Police Department.

If the conduct is not life threatening:

  • For a UCI student, contact the Office of Student Conduct.

  • For a UCI employee, contact Human Resources.

Persons Who Are Distressed

Distressed persons display persistent behaviors, such as: anxious, sad, irritable, withdrawn, confused, lacks motivation and/or concentration, seeks constant attention, demonstrates bizarre or erratic behavior, or expresses suicidal thoughts.

  • For a UCI student, contact the Counseling Center, Student Health Center, Campus Assault Resources and Education (CARE), or the UCI Police Department for help.

  • For a UCI employee, contact Human Resources, Guidance Resources Employee Assistance Program, or the UCI Police Department for help.

For consultation regarding disruptive or distressed individuals, please contact the UCI Consultation Team through the Office of the Clinical Social Worker.

If you discover a fire:
  • Extinguish the fire if you have been trained and if it is safe to do so.

  • Evacuate the immediate area and close doors behind you.

  • Pull the nearest fire alarm.

  • Call 911 if safe to do so. Otherwise, evacuate the building then call 911.

  • Do not re-enter the building until an "All Clear" is given by emergency responders.

If you hear a fire alarm:
  • Evacuate as soon as the alarm sounds.

  • Test closed doors with the back of your hand. DO NOT open doors if they are hot.

  • Use stairs only. Do not use elevators.
  • Proceed to the designated assembly area.

  • Do not re-enter the building until an "All Clear" is given by emergency responders.

Are you prepared for an emergency situation? Take these simply steps to improve the preparedness of you, your family, and your work colleagues.

Have A Kit

Keep an emergency kit at home, in your car, and in your office.

  • Water - one gallon per person per day for at least 3 days for drinking and sanitation.

  • Food - at least a 3 day supply of non-perishable food.

  • Battery operated Radio and Flashlight with extra batteries.

  • First Aid Kit.

  • Whistle.

  • All Purpose Tool.

  • Basic sanitation items like towelettes, garbage bags, hand sanitizer, tissues.

  • Change of clothes and sturdy shoes.

Make A Plan
  • Have an out-of-town contact for family members to report in to.

  • ICE your cell phone - identify who to call In Case of Emergency.

  • Be prepared to limit phone use to essential calls only. Text messages may go through when phone calls will not.

  • Select a family meeting location in case your house is not safe or accessible.

Be Informed
  • The Top 5 Hazards For UC Irvine are:

    • Catastrophic Earthquake.

    • Laboratory or Housing Fire.

    • Civil Disturbance.

    • Public Health Emergency.

    • Active Shooter/Workplace Violence.

  • Know what to do in case of an emergency on campus.

  • Know evacuation routes and the pre-designated assembly areas for the buildings you are in most frequently.

  • Inquire about the emergency plan for family members\' work and school.

  • Visit www.ready.gov for more information.

  • For campus emergency preparedness information visit www.police.uci.edu.

  • Sign up to receive zotALERT text messages at www.oit.uci.edu/zotalert.

Bomb threats usually come on the telephone and generally are made by individuals who want to create an atmosphere of general anxiety or panic. All bomb threats should be assumed to pose a legitimate danger to the UCI campus.

By Telephone:
  1. Take the caller seriously, but remain calm.

  2. Ask a lot of questions, such as: When will the bomb explode? Where is it located? What does it look like? What kind of bomb is it?

  3. Take notes on everything said and on your observations about background noise, voice characteristics, etc.

  4. If possible, have a co-worker call the UCI Police Department while you continue talking to the caller.

  5. Call 911 immediately after the threatening call.

  6. Notify your supervisor/department head.

  7. Campus police will determine if evacuation is necessary. If you do evacuate, move to an evacuation assembly area.

  8. Do not re-enter the area until instructed to do so.

• Stay calm. Do not panic. Move swiftly.

  • Safely stop your work and secure any hazardous materials or equipment before leaving.

  • Gather your personal belongings if safe to do so.

  • Proceed to the nearest safe exit.

  • Do not use elevators.

  • Proceed to the designated assembly area.

  • Wait for instructions from emergency responders.

  • Do not re-enter the building until an "All Clear" is given by emergency responders.

• Evacuate affected area.

  • Call 911.

  • Provide the dispatcher with information on the material type, quantity, and specific location of the spill or release.

  • Isolate the spill/release and deny entry to the area.

  • Notify EH&S at (949) 824-6200 if you have been exposed to a hazard or you have information about the release.

  • Follow instructions of emergency responders.

If you See Something, Say Something.

Immediately call 911 from a safe location if you are the victim of or witness to:

  • Assault.

  • Verbal or other threat of bodily harm.

  • Suspicious activity or suspicious packages/items.

  • Crimes in progress.

  • Weapons violations.

  • Activities presenting a serious risk to yourself or others.

Do not confront the suspect or block their exit.

Do not take unnecessary chances.

1. Persons with disabilities, access or functional needs are urged to self-identify and work with their supervisor, colleagues, classmates, and Zone Crew members to determine evacuation routes and methods, areas of safe refuge, and other emergency planning needs before an emergency occurs.

  2. In many cases, evacuation from the building may not be necessary or advisable. Evacuate when the fire alarms are activated, directed by emergency responders, or danger is imminent.

  3. Proceed to the nearest safe exit. Implement your individual emergency plan. Request assistance from others in the area if exit is difficult or obstructed.

  4. If unable to evacuate the building:

    1. Take safe refuge in a fire-rated stairwell. Close the door to keep smoke out. OR

    2. Evacuate "horizontally" to a room away from hazards. Close the doors, Signal rescuers by placing a sign in the window. Place wet cloths around and under the door to prevent smoke from entering. Call 911 and provide your location to the dispatcher. Follow their directions.

    3. If safe to do so, it is preferred that someone stay with the person with the disability.

    4. Designate one person to contact on-scene emergency personnel with location, nature of evacuation needs, etc.

Shelter-In-Place (SIP) simply means seeking immediate shelter inside a building due to a release of toxic chemicals, biological or radioactive materials to the outside air. If the outside air quality is threatened or compromised, sheltering in place keeps you inside an area offering more protection. Although rarely called for, SIP events usually last only a few hours.

Immediate Shelter-In-Place:
  • When the release is nearby and the need to seek shelter is immediate.
  • Stay inside a building.
  • If outside, enter the nearest building.
  • Remain in place until advised by emergency responders that it is safe to leave.
Delayed Shelter-In-Place
  • When a release occurs off campus and there is time (30 minutes or more) to move people to large, enclosed areas.
  • Follow directions of emergency responders to move quickly to SIP location.
  • Remain in place until advised by emergency responders that it is safe to leave.
  • You may be notified to Shelter-In-Place via Zone Crew members, emergency responders, zotmail, and ZotALERT text messages.

• Call 911.

  • Do not approach the victim unless it is safe to do so.

  • Send someone to meet and direct emergency responders.

  • Do not move the patient unless absolutely necessary.

  • Do not take seriously ill or injured persons to the Student Health Center.

  • Provide first aid if trained and if it is safe to do so.

• Turn off and unplug computers and other sensitive electrical equipment.

  • Keep freezers and refrigerators closed during the power outage.

  • Keep a flashlight with fresh batteries in the area.

  • Move cautiously to a lighted area.

  • Exits may be indicated by lighted signs.

  • Contact the Facilities Management Service Desk at (949) 824-5444.

• Do not touch or disturb the object/package.

  • Call 911, if safe to do so.

  • Notify a supervisor/department head.

  • Prepare to evacuate.

A Secure-In-Place notification may be issued when the UCI Police Department determines that there is a potential threat to the campus. When notified to Secure-In-Place, initiate action immediately. Take ALL zotALERTS seriously. You will be safest by placing a locked door or other barricade between you and the associated violence or danger.

How do I Secure-In-Place?
  • REMAIN CALM!
  • Find an interior room and lock or barricade the doors.
  • If there are other employees, students/visitors with you or in the vicinity, tell them to go to the closest office/classroom/lab/residence hall.
  • To minimize vulnerability, turn off lights, silence phones, and draw blinds.
  • Move away from doors and windows.
  • Move/use furniture to provide added protection.
  • Follow instructions from Police, Fire, Zone Crew team members, and other first responders.
  • DO NOT leave until an all-clear message is received.
What if I am outside?
  • If you are outside during a Secure-In-Place emergency you should seek shelter in a nearby building.
  • If you are unable to get inside a building, seek nearby shelter, e.g. large trees, walls, cars in a parking lot/garage, away from the danger area (if known).
  • Follow instructions from Police, Fire, Zone Crew team members, and other first responders.
  • Stay sheltered until an all-clear message is received.
What if I am in a classroom or lecture hall?
  • Notify class of "Secure-In-Place" order (students, if your professor or TA does not see the alert - notify them).
  • Lock or barricade the doors.
  • Turn off lights, silence phones, and draw blinds.
  • Move away from doors and windows.
  • Move/use furniture to provide added protection.
  • Follow instructions from Police, Fire, Zone Crew team members, and other first responders.
  • DO NOT leave until an all-clear message is received.

• Review the UCI Emergency Procedures Chart (aka "Red Flip Chart").

  • If you live on campus, have a copy of the chart posted in your dorm room or apartment.

  • Know what to do in case of an emergency on campus.

  • Evacuate the immediate area and close doors behind you.

  • Know the location of emergency blue light phones.

  • Know evacuation routes and the pre-designated assembly areas for the buildings you.

  • Sign up to receive zotALERT text messages at www.oit.uci.edu/zotalert

  • Work with your family to develop a Family Emergency Plan.

  • Have an emergency kit at home and in your car.

  • Test closed doors with the back of your hand. DO NOT open doors if they are hot.

• Have a copy of the UCI Emergency Procedures Chart (aka "Red Flip Chart") accessible in your workspace, laboratories, and classroom(s).

  • Know your role during an emergency.

  • Get to know your Zone Captain and the Zone Crew members in your area.

  • Know evacuation routes and the pre-designated assembly areas for the buildings you are in most frequently.

Faculty members should be prepared to direct their students to assembly areas in the event of an emergency.
  • Know the emergency plan and continuity/recovery plan for your department.

  • Sign up to receive zotALERT text messages at www.oit.uci.edu/zotalert

  • Have an emergency kit in your office, in your car, and at home.

  • Contact the campus Emergency Services Manager at x4-7147 if you are interested in a preparedness presentation for your department.

  • Get involved on campus.

    • Become a Zone Crew member. Contact your Zone Captain and visit http://police.uci.edu/em/ZoneCrew.html for more information.

    • Become a Campus Search and Rescue (CSAR) Team Member. Visit www.police.uci.edu/em/csar.html for training sessions and more information.

    • Become First Aid and CPR trained. The ARC offers free or low cost classes conducted by the American Red Cross. Go to www.campusrec.uci.edu, Classes and Clinics for details.
